entry.content:
Book: Elantris, by Brandon Sanderson (2005) (4)20130228
I read seven chapters today.

Compare: "Hrathen would ever bear the scars of what he had done,
but it was better that one man suffer than an entire nation
continue in heresy." (Elantris, p203) vs "Behold the Lord slayeth
the wicked to bring forth his righteous purposes. It is better that
one man should perish than that a nation should dwindle and perish
in unbelief." (1 Nephi 4:13)

Given that I know what will happen in the end, it is exciting to
see the foreshadowing (and foreboding) about the deadly monks of
the East. It's very cool.

Another way to look at what Raoden is doing in Elantris: Since he
giving everyone something to do and their lack of anything to do
was making them miserable, in a sense he is saying that if you (a)
live forever, (b) don't change/grow, and (c) don't have anything to
do, then you will be miserable. This is interesting from a *REDACTED*
perspective, because that describes perfectly what non-*REDACTED*
Heaven is like, whereas in the *REDACTED* concept of Heaven, everyone
has purpose and growth, and thus, according to /Elantris/,
happiness.

I really enjoyed how Raoden "converted" Taan with love and
reminding him of the beauty of the world.

Book: Elantris, by Brandon Sanderson (2005) (3)20130227
I read two more chapters.

I like the discussion of the holy language of Jaddeth and where
converts should have to learn it. I think there's something similar
in *REDACTED*ism and English because all translations have to made from
English because the source of the Book of *REDACTED* is not available.

I like the discussion of using the Seons in Jaddeth's empire. It
is reminiscent to me of Islamic fundamentalists using technology
for their military purposes, yet claiming that technology designed
for improving people's lives is immoral.

I like that when Raoden meets with Karata the revelation is that
children are the greatest happiness in life and all toil is worth
it if you can take care of them.

My wife had the brilliant idea to see each of the characters as a
different model of leadership. Raoden has optimism and can give
people hope, by putting them to productive ends. Hrathen and
Sarene are both calculating and political, but I think they
represent those skills being put towards bad and good ends, so
they are interesting exemplars.

entry.title: Book: Elantris, by Brandon Sanderson (2005) (2)
entry.content:
Book: Elantris, by Brandon Sanderson (2005) (2)20130224
I read quite a few more chapters today and having a smattering of
thoughts.

- The contrast between Dilaf's zealotry and Hrathen's practicality
is very interesting. For example, Dilaf says something like
"Nothing can stand in Jaddeth's way" as an argument against why
they should do some plan for the Kae. Hrathen's response is,
"Then why isn't the whole world converted?" One idea I can see in
this is that often the "sophisticated theology" of the
upper-class of religionists make them have almost totally
different beliefs than the lower-class, to the point that the
upper-class may not even seem like they believe at all. I get
this impression about *REDACTED*ism a lot when people talk about how
to treat new converts, especially those in far away places.

- Hrathen gives a very *REDACTED* explanation of the Svarkiss: "Nothing
is more bitter than a soul who had had its chance and thrown it
away." This is the way that Satan and his followers are discussed
a lot in *REDACTED*ism and how many ex-members are seen.

- A poignant moment in one of Raoden's chapters is the discussion
of how Elantris was not built for normal people to live
in---there are no wells or furnances or lights---and that after
the fall of AonDor it is totally desolate. How is this related to
Modern worry about a too heavy reliance on technology and the
desire to train ourselves to live without in times of disaster?

- I like that Sarene's plan to change the government is so
libertarian and capitalistic. You can almost see the debate on
what to do as a debate about how to intervene in communist
countries and/or get them to change for the better. Freedom
works.

Later in the day I played for another hour and finished the first
big mission and then started the second. The intro to the second

Right when I met him though, was an insanely difficult fight with

noticed that I could get a ninja attack on them, so I tried
spamming that while parrying and dodging... and I beat them in

restart and getting some healing items or something.

This game definitely feels like a Platinum game, but it's really
unique compared to Vanquish or Bayonetta in what you're
doing... but it "feels" the same. It's great.

through a few rooms. There was a really rough part with some of

high. Eventually I was able to do it because of a fluke: he fell

The moment in the story of seeing all the detached brains is

entry.title: Book: Elantris, by Brandon Sanderson (2005)
entry.content:
Book: Elantris, by Brandon Sanderson (2005)20130223
I read this book once before, but my wife is reading it for her
book club, so I decided to read it again to help her think of
things to talk about during the meeting.

I read the first two chapters today and thought a lot about the
book from a *REDACTED* perspective. (I'm *REDACTED* and so is Sanderson.)
Here are a few of the ideas, plus some that aren't really related
to *REDACTED*ism.

- Prior to the fall of Elantris, it is almost a *REDACTED*-like notion
of divinity, because anyone can achieve it, although it is given,
rather than earned, so grace is emphasized far more than works.

- In the treatment of people who receive the eternal "life" of
Elantris, what can we learn about how charitable people are?
As far as we know, there's nothing contagious about their
condition and there's no downside for their community, but they
are treated as dead, rejected, and locked up; all for something
they did not choose and have no control over. I can't help but
think of how many homosexuals feel they are treated by popular
American culture.

- The thing that is horrifying about life in Elantris is that it is
eternal and every pain you've ever felt stays with you forever. I
think this is a clear projection of what *REDACTED*ism says Hell is
like: all will inherit eternal life, whether they are "good" or
"bad", but if they reject the Atonement, then they will not allow
the Savior to absolve them of the pain they feel for their
sins. Elantris is a concrete version of this: rather than having
their pain and mistakes washed away so that they "remember them
no more", they remember and feel them forever. Elantris is *REDACTED*
Hell.

- Given that I know what's going to happen in the book, it is
interesting to see Elantris as Hell (or rather, the world without
the Atonement), because essential it makes Raoden Christ: He was
the son of the king of the world that controlled Elantris; he
suffers the same condition as the Elantris and leaves "his
throne on high"; once there, he feels their pain and will teach
them a new way to life with purpose; then, he will redeem them
and restore Elantris to its ancient glory.

- I love the character of Sarene, because she's such a strong and
determined woman in a community (i.e. the king's court) that
doesn't respect women, as shown by their first interaction
together. It is fun to see what she does and to gradually learn
who she is... I think she's a great role model and a surprising
character to be written by a young man in a fantasy novel.

- Clearly the parts that are literally about religion are likely
to be influence in some ways by *REDACTED*ism. I think in this
context though, I see the *REDACTED* understanding of Catholicism at
work. Hrathen and his religion is overtly foreign. He is adamant
that their job is not "love" the people but to "help" the
people, as if they are not the same.

On the other hand, there are aspects about his description of
Derethi that are like the popular understanding of *REDACTED*ism: it
has a rigid military-like structure with a lot of authority and
delegation; a revered prophet; etc. Then again, there's a lot of
Islam there too with the concept of the Caliphate.

Another relevant thing is that the language of religious zeal
Sanderson uses is distinctly *REDACTED*: Dilaf is converted and reads
the two sets of Derethi scriptures in the same night, reminiscent
of Parley P. Pratt and countless other *REDACTED* converts.
